verses.text: After twenty years, during which Solomon built the house of the LORD and his own house,
verses.comment: Solomon's building timeline matches 1 Kings. 'House of the LORD' rendered 'temple'.

verses.text: Solomon rebuilt the cities that Huram had given to him and settled the people of Israel there.
verses.comment: Huram is same as Hiram; possible variation in city ownership noted between Kings and Chronicles.

verses.text: Solomon went to Hamath-zobah and captured it.
verses.comment: Hamath-zobah: prominent city in Aram/Syria; not all translations distinguish 'Hamath' from 'Zobah'.

verses.text: He built Tadmor in the wilderness and all the storage cities that he had built in Hamath.
verses.comment: Tadmor reads instead of 'Tamar' as in some texts. 'Storage cities' is same as 'store cities'.

verses.text: He also built Upper Beth-horon and Lower Beth-horon, fortified cities with walls, gates, and bars;
verses.comment: Details match the Hebrew text; 'bars' indicate secure gates.

verses.text: and Baalath, and all the storage cities that belonged to Solomon, and all the cities for chariots and for horsemen, and all that Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout all the land under his rule.
verses.comment: Rendered 'all that Solomon desired to build,' preserving nuance of sovereign choice.

verses.text: All the people who remained of the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not of Israel,
verses.comment: Lists five Canaanite nations; matches the original closely.

verses.text: their descendants who remained in the land after them, whom the people of Israel did not destroy—Solomon made them forced laborers, as they are to this day.
verses.comment: 'Forced laborers' modernizes 'servants' or 'bondservants'; reflects historical status.

verses.text: But Solomon did not make Israelites serve as forced laborers for his work; they were men of war, commanders, chief officers, chariot commanders, and horsemen.
verses.comment: Differentiates labor practices for Israelites vs. non-Israelites.

verses.text: These were the chief officers of King Solomon, two hundred and fifty who supervised the people.
verses.comment: 'Two hundred and fifty' matches MT; 1 Kings gives a different number.

verses.text: Solomon brought Pharaoh's daughter up from the city of David to the house he had built for her. For he said, 'My wife shall not live in the house of David, king of Israel, because it is holy, since the ark of the LORD has entered it.'
verses.comment: 'Holy' reflects sanctification related to the ark. Direct speech preserved.

verses.text: Then Solomon offered burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar of the LORD that he had built before the porch,

according to the daily custom, offering according to the commandment of Moses, on the Sabbaths, the new moons, and the appointed feasts, three times each year—the Feast of Unleavened Bread, the Feast of Weeks, and the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: Feasts named for clarity: Passover/Unleavened Bread, Weeks (Pentecost), Booths (Tabernacles).

verses.text: He established, according to the arrangement of David his father, the divisions of the priests for their service, and the Levites for their duties, to give praise and minister before the priests as the daily custom required, and the gatekeepers in their divisions at each gate; for this was the commandment of David, the man of God.
verses.comment: 'Man of God' reflects respect for David; duties clarified per original Hebrew intent.

verses.text: They did not deviate from the king's command to the priests and Levites concerning any matter or their treasury.
So all the work of Solomon was accomplished from the day the foundation of the house of the LORD was laid until it was finished. The house of the LORD was completed.
verses.comment: Completion summarized, following structure of original text.

verses.text: Then Solomon went to Ezion-geber and Eloth on the shore of the sea, in the land of Edom.
verses.comment: Locations reflect Red Sea port towns; geography maintained.

verses.text: Huram sent him ships by his servants, as well as sailors who knew the sea. They went with Solomon's servants to Ophir and brought back four hundred and fifty talents of gold to King Solomon.
verses.comment: Amount of gold matches original text. Aphir maintained as 'Ophir'.
